body: Please upgrade gRPC on the Go side to the latest version and confirm that the issue persists. There was a fixed bug in Go's flow control logic that I suspect is the cause. Please re-open this issue if you can reproduce with the latest Go-grpc release (1.4). Thanks!
cf. https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/issues/1192

I no longer get that issue, but the client never receives any responses (even though the server is sending them).

Behavior looks like:

Python client sends request to golang server
Golang server response with stream of responses
When stream ends, python client returns but has none of the responses

This is on the newest versions of both grpc-go and grpc-python

Great! Pretty sure the original behavior you observed was related to the bug I referenced. The new issue is weird though. Can you please reduce it to a minimal test case we can reproduce? (Off the top of my head, are you sure another process—a previous version of the program—is not listening on the same port?)

Resolved it by setting MaxSendMsgSize to something larger on the server side.

Looks like the upgrade on the golang side added a limit for that. Caught it by sending a unary RPC that request the same amount of data in one "batch" of the streaming RPC, and got the actual exception.

A bit weird that the Streaming RPC doesn't raise that error, but swallows silently... Should probably raise in there.

Glad that it works now! If you think that behavior with respect to MaxSendMsgSize is problematic, please let the gRPC-go team know by raising an issue on grpc/grpc-go issue tracker so it'll get addressed or resolved (this one is focused on languages based on the C core). Thanks!

Glad that it works now! If you think that behavior with respect to MaxSendMsgSize is problematic, please let the gRPC-go team know by raising an issue on [grpc/grpc-go issue tracker](https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/issues) so it'll get addressed or resolved (this one is focused on languages based on the C core). Thanks!

To clarify, I'm not sure if this a gRPC-go problem or a grpc-core problem.

It could either be 

1. golang server not sending the exception back so the python side never raises
2. python side does get an exception back from the golang server, but never raises it

This warrants a bit more investigation. Should I open up a ticket with them as well or should we confirm here first?
I get that same issue regardless of grpc python version (all 1.1.3+), so that certainly makes it _seem_ like it's a grpc-go issue. I'll open up a ticket there.
Yes, I think since they have freshly changed things related to the max message size, it is more immediately addressable by the go side.

Thought I'd mention, this no longer happens consistently, but happens from time to time with many streaming RPCs in production.

I've been unable to reproduce this locally. Any thoughts? This is on v1.4.x

Can you characterize the streaming RPCs that may be causing the issues? (Like are they big, fast, how frequent?)

It's unlikely but there might be more overflow issues with the flow control. Can you please try 
`GRPC_TRACE=all GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG ./server` on the python/C side and capture some trace info when the crash occurs? If `GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG` is too verbose, you can try less verbose settings too.
